questions.text: Neuroendocrine enteropancreatic tumours (NEEPTs) include tumours developing from the pancreatic islets and the duodenal loop, and those developing from gut serotonin-secreting cells (mid-gut carcinoids). When functioning, they are rare tumours with frequently inconsistent clinical and biological characteristics. Entero pancreatic tumour is usually associated with which MEN syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MEN 1 Entero pancreatic tumour is seen in 30-70% of MEN 1 Syndrome. MEN 1, 80–100% develop non-functional pNETs (most are microscopic with 0–13% large/symptomatic), and functional pNETs occur in 20–80% in different series , with a mean of 54% developing Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, 18% insulinomas, 3% glucagonoma, 3% VIPomas, and <1% GRFomas or somatostatinomas .

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. MTC, Pheochromocytoma and Parathyroid adenoma Option: C. MTC, Pheochromocytoma, and anomalies. Option: D. Parathyroid adenoma, Pituitary adenoma, Reproductive organ tumors.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with increased thirst, increased frequency of urination, and weight loss for the past 7 months. She also tells you that her father is a diabetic. Further evaluation reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? Body mass index - 21 kg/m2 Fasting blood sugar -252 mg/d Glycosylated haemoglobin -8.2% Urinalysis for ketones Negative
questions.correct_answer: C. Maturity-onset diabetes of the young
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maturity-onset diabetes of the young This clinical scenario is suggestive of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY). MODY is a monogenic form of diabetes mellitus that is transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion. It affects young adults 25 years of age. It occurs due to reduced insulin secretion. Etiological factors of type 1 and 2 diabetes such as insulin resistance, obesity, and antibodies are not associated with this condition. Stable hyperglycemia is usually seen, hence complications like diabetic ketoacidosis are uncommon. Macrovascular complications like hyperlipidemia or hypertension are not seen. It is treated with insulin and sulfonylureas.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Type 1 DM - Type 1 diabetes is thought to be caused by an autoimmune reaction (the body attacks itself by mistake) . This reaction destroys the cells in the pancreas that make insulin, called beta cells. This process can go on for months or years before any symptoms appear. So it usually occurs in older individuals. Option: B. Type 2 DM - is associated with insulin resistance which leads to hyperglycemia. Option: D. LADA - The cause of LADA is the development of autoantibodies against pancreatic cells, insulin, or enzymes involved in pancreatic functions. Antibodies affecting the pancreas and its function may influence the way the body responds to blood sugar.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her HbA1c level is 11.1%. What is the initial drug of choice?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Insulin Insulin is the best initial drug of choice when HbA1c is > 9% at diagnosis. Insulin is used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes in the following cases: Inadequate glycemic control with 2 or more oral agents HbA1c> 9% at diagnosis In patients with HbA1c< 9% , metformin is the drug of choice.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Metformin - is not preferred if HBA1C levels are already so high . Option: B. Glimepiride - Glimepiride is used to treat high blood sugar levels caused by type 2 diabetes. It may be used alone or in combination with insulin or another oral medicine such as metformin. In type 2 diabetes, insulin produced by the pancreas is not able to get sugar into the cells of the body where it can work properly. Option: D. Sitagliptin - Sitagliptin is used along with diet and exercise and sometimes with other medications to lower blood sugar levels in adults with type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: A type 2 diabetic patient who was recently started on treatment complains of frequent urination, fever, and burning micturition. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dapagliflozin This clinical scenario is suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI). This adverse effect occurs as a result of dapagliflozin use.

Highyeild:

The group of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 or SGLT-2 inhibitors includes drugs like dapagliflozin and canagliflozin. These drugs prevent glucose reabsorption in the renal tubules and cause loss of sodium and glucose. This loss in urine is responsible for infection due to increased glucose in urine - greater chances of bacterial survival in urine. Dapagliflozin is also responsible for some important side effects like - osteoporosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - Metformin - not associated with UTI, can cause lactic acidosis and vit b12 deficiency. Option: C - Glipizide - Glipizide is in a class of medications called Glipizide lowers blood sugar by causing the pancreas to produce insulin. Side effects - Nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, diarrhoea, constipation, upset stomach, headache, and weight gain may occur. Option: D. Exenatide - the most common side effect is nausea.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is hospitalized with pneumonia. He is a known patient with type 2 diabetes. During the hospital stay, his appetite is poor and his oral intake is irregular. The physician decides to administer rapid-acting insulin based on high blood sugar values. Which of the following would he use?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glulisine This clinical scenario describes the sliding scale method. Rapid-acting insulins such as glulisine is used.

Highyeild:

The sliding scale refers to the administration of insulin as a bolus dose based on the blood sugar level before the meal. Using this principle, the insulin dose is titrated every time according to pre-meal glucose levels to determine insulin requirement. Hence, rapid-acting insulin is preferred. This method requires a fixed carbohydrate intake at every meal. It is used for the short-term management of hospitalized patients especially when the frequency or quantity of food intake is very variable. It does not physiologically deliver insulin, hence is not a preferred long-term strategy for glycemic control.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the casualty with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. His blood sugar levels are 427 mg/dl and his urine ketones are 3+. He is started on IV normal saline and insulin infusion. Which of the following should he be monitored for?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypokalemia This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis, which is treated with insulin infusion. Insulin causes an intracellular shift of K ions resulting in a decreased extracellular K" ion concentration. This results in hypokalemia.

questions.text: Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome(ZES) is caused by?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastrinoma It is a Neuroendocrine Tumor that secretes Gastrin , the resultant hypergastrinemia causes gastric acid hypersecretion. Chronic hypersecretion characteristically causes peptic ulcer disease, often severe and refractory to standard medical treatment, as well as diarrhoea.

Clinical situations that suggest the diagnosis are Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) with diarrhoea PUD with multiple lesions and in unusual locations like the second part of the duodenum and beyond PUD that is persistent and refractory to treatment PUD in association with MEN I PUD without H.pylori infection

questions.correct_answer: A. Fast up to 72 hours with serum glucose, C-peptide, proinsulin, and Insulin measurements every 4-8 hours
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fast up to 72 hours with serum glucose, C-peptide, proinsulin, and Insulin measurements every 4-8 hours The gold standard test for diagnosis of Insulinoma is a supervised 72 hours Fast test. The diagnosis of Insulinoma requires demonstration of inappropriately high levels of plasma insulin and C-peptide in the presence of documented hypoglycemia (Achieved by 72-hour Fast test) The test is considered positive at any time when blood glucose levels drop to 40 mg/dl, and serum Insulin levels are recorded to be greater than 6 micro units /ml.

questions.text: A 70-year-old Caucasian woman was referred to the Department of Dermatology with persistent subacute eczema affecting her lower extremities and groin area that had been present for 12 months. She was treated with topical and oral steroids with no improvement. Her medical history revealed a long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus and recurrent episodes of deep-vein thrombosis in her right leg despite anticoagulant therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glucagonoma A glucagonoma is a NET of the pancreas that secretes excessive amounts of glucagon, which causes a distinct syndrome characterized by dermatitis, glucose intolerance or diabetes, and weight loss. Glucagono-mas principally occur between 45 and 70 years of age. The tumour is clinically heralded by a characteristic dermatitis (migratory necrolytic erythema) (67–90%), accompanied by glucose intolerance (40–90%), weight loss (66–96%), anaemia (33–85%), diarrhoea (15–29%), and thromboembolism (11–24% ).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . The Whipple's triad consisting of symptoms of hypoglycemia, low blood glucose levels and symptoms resolving with glucose ingestion is characteristic of Insulinoma. Option: B. Gastrinoma presents with abdominal pain, diarrhoea and GERD . Option: C. - VIPoma presents with features of watery diarrhoea, hypokalemia, hypochlorhydria and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with a history of large-volume watery diarrhoea along with complaints of lethargy, nausea, vomiting, muscle weakness and cramps. The diarrhoea is present even after 48 hours fast. Lab results show hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, and hypochlorhydria. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

VIPoma VIPomas are NETs that secrete excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), which causes a distinct syndrome characterized by large-volume diarrhoea, hypokalemia, and dehydration. This syndrome also is called Verner-Morrison syndrome, pancreatic cholera, and WDHA syndrome for watery diarrhoea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria, which some patients develop.

Highyeild:

The principal symptoms are large-volume diarrhoea (100%) severe enough to cause hypokalemia (80–100%), dehydration (83%), hypochlorhydria (54–76%), and flushing (20%). The diarrhoea is secretory in nature, persisting during fasting, and is almost always >1 L/d and in 70% is >3 L/d. In a number of studies, the diarrhoea was intermittent initially in up to half the patients. Most patients do not have accompanying steatorrhea (16%), and the increased stool volume is due to increased excretion of sodium and potassium, which, with the anions, accounts for the osmolality of the stool. Patients frequently have hyperglycemia (25–50%) and hypercalcemia (25–50%). VIP is a 28-amino-acid peptide that is an important neurotransmitter, ubiquitously present in the CNS and GI tract. Its known actions include stimulation of SI chloride secretion as well as effects on smooth-muscle contractility, inhibition of acid secretion, and vasodilatory effects, which explain most features of the clinical syndrome.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- The Whipple`s triad consisting of symptoms of hypoglycemia, low blood glucose levels and symptoms resolving with glucose ingestion is characteristic of Insulinoma. Option B- Gastrinoma presents with abdominal pain, diarrhoea and GERD. Option D- Glucagonoma presents with a triad of rash, glucose intolerance and weight loss.
